description: From Middle English sich, siche, from Old English sīċ (“a watercourse; sike”), from Proto-West Germanic *sīk, from Proto-Germanic *sīką (“slow flowing water; a trickle”).

entries.meaning: (now chiefly dialectal) A brook; ditch; gutter; drain; ravine.

description: Shortening of situation, with phonetic respelling.

examples: So here's the sitch: Bruce Banner and Betty Ross Talbot are falling from roughly eight miles high.
